At that time, the World-Honored One told the bhiká¹£us:
A wheel-turning sage king has these four unprecedented dharmas.

What are the four?ğŸ”½Here, the wheel-turning sage king is loved by all the people, never harming them, like a father to his children;ğŸ”½the wheel-turning sage king is also like this, cherishing the people without ever becoming angry towards them, like a father with an only child. This is called the wheel-turning sage king's first unprecedented dharma.
Or, when the wheel-turning sage king travels among the people, they all rejoice like a child with their father. This is called the wheel-turning sage king's second unprecedented dharma.

Furthermore, when the wheel-turning sage king abides and does not travel, those people who see him all become joyful. When the wheel-turning sage king speaks the Dharma to the people, those who hear it all become joyful. At that time, the people hear the wheel-turning sage king speak the Dharma and are never satisfied. This is called the third unprecedented Dharma of the wheel-turning sage king.

Furthermore, when the wheel-turning sage king sits and does not travel, those people who see him all become joyful. The wheel-turning sage king instructs the people, saying, This should be done, this should not be done. This can be associated with, this cannot be associated with. If one does this, one will obtain blessings for a long time without end. If one does this, one will suffer for a long time without rest. The people hear the wheel-turning sage king's instructions like this and are never satisfied with the joy. This is called the wheel-turning sage king's unprecedented Dharma.

If Ä€nanda the monk silently goes to the assembly of nuns, those who see him are all delighted. When Ä€nanda the monk preaches the Dharma, those who hear the Dharma are all delighted. The assembly of nuns never tires of hearing Ä€nanda speak the Dharma. This is called Ä€nanda the monk's second unprecedented quality.

At that time, the bhiká¹£us heard what the Buddha taught, and joyfully undertook to follow it.

The Buddha Speaks the SÅ«tra of the Four Unprecedented Events. The name of this sÅ«tra and the translator are the same in all the various canons, but the text and meaning of the two versions of the Song and Qi dynasties are completely the same. From beginning to end, it only speaks of the merits of building a stÅ«pa. At the end, it concludes with the name the Dharma of the Unprecedented, but throughout the entire sÅ«tra there is no meaning of the word four. This sÅ«tra of the Tang version speaks of the four unprecedented events of a wheel-turning sage king, using it as a metaphor for Ä€nanda also having four unprecedented events.

According to the Kaiyuan lu, in the ruo case, there is the SÅ«tra of the Four Unprecedented Events, which says it is the same text as the Chapter on the Eight Difficulties in the Ekottarika Ä€gama, translated differently.
Now, examining the sÅ«tra of the Tang version, it is precisely this.

The sÅ«tra of the Song and Qi versions is precisely the SÅ«tra of the Unprecedented Events in the hui case above, translated by an unknown person in the Later Han dynasty, listed in the ancient and old records.

The Song canon, in the Ru fascicle, lost the true Four Unprecedented Sutras and obtained the Hui fascicle's Unprecedented Sutra, considering it to be missing four characters, and thus added the four characters to be compiled here, which is a mistake.
Alas!
This mistake has four faults:
Losing the true Four Unprecedented Sutras is the first.
Having two copies of the Unprecedented Sutra is the second.
Moreover, it is mistranslated as translated by Dharmaraká¹£a, the third.
It is Mahayana, yet it is suppressed and compiled in this Small Vehicle canon, the fourth.

Therefore, the Song canon is discarded and the Dunhuang manuscript is taken. Later scholars who wish to know what sutra is discarded now, please see the Hui fascicle's Unprecedented Sutra, which is it.
